pros: It is a very nice institution.
cons: The students vary a lot in terms of academic interest and dedication.

review_title: The writing is on the wall...
pros: The students make the work in the classroom rewarding.
cons: The college has been going downhill for a long time, but the choices made by administration during and since the pandemic have been catastrophic. They have cut frontline staff down to the bare minimum while bloating mid- and upper-level administration, have outsourced numerous offices like human resources, the campus bookstore, and the tutoring center to corporate entities, and have divested themselves of half of the School of Arts and Sciences through early retirement and voluntary severance packages, followed by the "un-tenuring" of more junior arts and humanities faculty.

pros: The work relationship between colleague is welcoming.
cons: Students aren’t enthusiastic about the campus

job_title: Writer and Content Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The bathrooms are spacious and lovely
cons: Where does one begin? I’ll say this: getting paid monthly was a…fascinating choice, as was the creative benefits package. Lots of heartbreak overall, but maybe it’s different now?

pros: You will meet some great people but they won't stay long anymore

pros: Enjoyed the students and the fellow faculty for the most part.

review_title: One Can Only Hope They Turn it Around
job_title: Visiting Lecturer/Lab Manager in Mamaroneck, NY
pros: Beautiful campus, great parking, food options are decent. Students are very nice. A lot of  good, hard working, talented and humble people work there. Decent resources for teaching.
cons:
When I arrived, every other person I met was new. When I had decided it was time for me to move on, almost everyone who had started when I did had also chosen to move on. I would call numerous administration departments wildly disorganized, completely lacking communication and barely enough cooperation for the school to function at all. Different departments were continually hostile to each other. Hierarchies were not established/respected. 
The posted job description was different than what the department wanted, which was different than what my contract said, which was different than what they decided they wanted a month into the job. I accommodated my multiple bosses different wishes as best I could. But everything was someone else's fault (the person who wrote my contract had moved on, the person who wrote the job description had been fired...). 
It was exhausting, unrewarding and frustrating. I was so glad when my contract was up.

pros:
A small college with small departments, you have the ability to learn a lot of different skills and work on projects you normally wouldn't in a larger settings. 

Great vacation and sick time benefits.

Work/life balance was great.
cons:
Consistent layoffs. 
Tight budgets. 
Little room for growth outside of your position.
Many departments, faculty and staff have been there for a while and are set in their ways. 
A lot of pushback on any attempts at change from students and faculty.

pros: Lots of support and opportunity to grow in student on-campus jobs. This job as a Peer Mentor allows for lots of one-on-one engagement with students, as well as opportunities for event planning and faculty collaboration. Outside opportunities come up once in a while as well. Main skills I've gained/refined include public speaking, research and development, organization, and business email etiquette.
cons: I get paid, but not for all of the efforts I make (planning events, attending classes I'm assigned).

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Port Chester, NY
pros: Professional respect and consideration.Schedule was mutually agreed upon and flexible. Colleagues were dedicated to our students. Location and access to outside the campus was a plus.
cons: Job was privatized to an outside entity.The new employers cleaned house and implemented a cookie cutter program . It made for a sad departure.

job_title: Assistant Women's Basketball Coach in Purchase, NY
pros:
- It is in a great location.
- I played here and have a connection with people here.
- They provide me with housing and a meal stipend.
- I have a bunch of different responsibilities within the program.
cons:
- I played here and have been coaching here for 3 years, so I need to expand my horizons.
- It is a very small school.
- I currently have no place to grow as an employee here.

pros: The campus is beautiful and their recent changes have set the college on a better path.  They offer many jobs to students in numerous departments.
cons: Freshman do not often get jobs because many departments hire at the end of the school year before the new students arrive. The budgets are very tight for new employees-both students and professional staff.

pros: Nice people. Friendly atmosphere. Great work/life balance. Management is great and they are open to hear new ideas, always looking to outperform previous goals. Open minded and professional.
cons:
At times lack of organization between project transitions.
Fluctuation between extremely busy periods of high demand and low demand.
